contentrichtext.text: {{distinguish|Deviation (statistics)}} In [[statistics]], '''deviance''' is a quality of fit statistic for a model that is often used for [[statistical hypothesis testing]]. It is a generalization, to cases where model-fitting is achieved by [[maximum likelihood]], of the idea of using the sum of squared residuals in [[ordinary least squares]]. ==Definition== The deviance for a model ''M''<sub>0</sub>, based on a dataset ''y'', is defined as:<ref>{{cite journal | last= Nelder | first = J.A. |authorlink = John Nelder | first2 = R.W.M. |last2 = Wedderburn |authorlink2 = Robert Wedderburn (statistician) | title = Generalized Linear Models | year=1972 | journal = [[Journal of the Royal Statistical Society]]. Series A (General) | volume= 135 |issue=3 | pages=370â€“384 | doi= 10.2307/2344614 | jstor= 2344614 }}</ref><ref name=McN>McCullagh and Nelder (1989){{Page needed|date=November 2011}}</ref> :<math>D(y) = -2 \Big( \log \big( p(y|\hat \theta_0)\big)-\log \big(p(y|\hat \theta_s)\big)\Big).\,</math> Here <math>\hat \theta_0</math> denotes the fitted values of the parameters in the model ''M''<sub>0</sub>, while <math>\hat \theta_s</math> denotes the fitted parameters for the "full model" (or "saturated model"): both sets of fitted values are implicitly functions of the observations ''y''. Here the '''full model''' is a model with a parameter for every observation so that the data are fitted exactly. This expression is simply −2 times the [[likelihood function|log-likelihood ratio]] of the reduced model compared to the full model. The deviance is used to compare two models – in particular in the case of [[generalized linear model]]s where it has a similar role to residual variance from [[ANOVA]] in linear models ([[Residual sum of squares|RSS]]). Suppose in the framework of the GLM, we have two nested models, ''M<sub>1</sub>'' and ''M<sub>2</sub>''. In particular, suppose that ''M<sub>1</sub>'' contains the parameters in ''M<sub>2</sub>'', and ''k'' additional parameters. Then, under the null hypothesis that ''M<sub>2</sub>'' is the true model, the difference between the deviances for the two models follows an approximate [[chi-squared distribution]] with ''k''-degrees of freedom.<ref name=McN/> Some usage of the term "deviance" can be confusing. According to Collett:<ref>Collett (2003){{Page needed|date=November 2011}}</ref> : "the quantity <math>-2 \log \big( p(y|\hat \theta_0)\big) </math> is sometimes referred to as a ''deviance''. This is [...] inappropriate, since unlike the deviance used in the context of generalized linear modelling, <math>-2 \log \big( p(y|\hat \theta_0)\big)</math> does not measure deviation from a model that is a perfect fit to the data." However, since the principal use is in the form of the difference of the deviances of two models, this confusion in definition is unimportant. ==See also== *[[Pearson's chi-squared test]], an alternative quality of fit statistic for [[generalized linear models]] for count data. *[[Hosmer-Lemeshow test]], a quality of fit statistic that can be used for binary data. *[[Akaike information criterion]] *[[Deviance information criterion]] *[[Peirce's criterion]] *[[Discrepancy function]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *{{cite book|last1=McCullagh|first1=Peter|last2=Nelder|first2=John|authorlink1 = Peter McCullagh|authorlink2 = John Nelder|title = Generalized Linear Models, Second Edition|publisher = Chapman & Hall/CRC|year = 1989|isbn=0-412-31760-5 }} *{{cite book|last1=Collett|first1=David|authorlink1 =|title = Modelling Survival Data in Medical Research, Second Edition|publisher = Chapman & Hall/CRC|year = 2003|isbn=1-58488-325-1 }} ==External links== *[http://userwww.sfsu.edu/~efc/classes/biol710/Glz/Generalized%20Linear%20Models.htm Generalized Linear Models] - Edward F.
